awd_titl_txt: Collaborative proposal:  Evaluating phenotypic plasticity's role in adaptive evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Many organisms can respond to changes in their environment by dramatically altering their morphology, behavior, or physiology, and the widespread occurrence of this ability has provoked a spirited debate. On the one hand, many biologists maintain that the flexibility to change appearance, behavior or physiology are of no relevance to evolution, because evolution requires genetic change. On the other hand, a growing number of researchers have suggested that such flexibility plays a critical role in evolution by jump-starting genetic change. This research will help resolve this controversy by investigating whether changes in appearance, behavior and/or physiology precede (and enable) the evolutionary origins of major, new, genetically-encoded features. The research will specifically evaluate whether pre-existing, diet-induced flexibility has contributed to the evolution of a novel, complex body form in spadefoot frogs. Thus, not only will this research provide important insights into the evolutionary process, it will also shed new light onto one of biology's enduring mysteries: how complex features originate. The research will also promote educational outreach by training school children and undergraduate students and by organizing public talks at museums.

This research will test the Plasticity-First hypothesis of adaptive evolution. To do so, the proposed research will focus on spadefoot toads. Like most frogs, tadpoles in the genus Scaphiopus develop only into a typical 'omnivore' morph. By contrast, tadpoles in the genus Spea exhibit striking plasticity: depending on their diet, they develop into either omnivores or a novel 'carnivore' morph. Interestingly, certain components of this distinctive carnivore morph can be diet-induced in Scaphiopus. Moreover, some Spea populations have secondarily lost the omnivore-carnivore plasticity and become monomorphic. Indeed, in some populations, selection has favored the near fixation of the carnivore morph. Thus, as a group, spadefoots appear to represent different stages in the evolution of the novel carnivore morph: from its possible initial induction (in Scaphiopus), to its refinement as part of a novel developmental 'switch' (in many Spea populations), to its ultimate fixation (in some Spea populations). The planned research will evaluate whether this novel carnivore phenotype arose through plasticity-first evolution by contrasting development, genetic variation, and performance in different species/populations that serve as different evolutionary stages in the origins of this distinctive form. In doing so, the research will evaluate the critical predictions of the plasticity-first hypothesis. This research will thereby help to clarify plasticity's role in evolutionary innovation and provide a roadmap for others to test the plasticity-first hypothesis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: We are often taught that the environment shapes the evolution of novel traits through natural selection of pre-existing variation. But can trait variation be generated by the environment, itself? Scientists are exploring the role of the environment in generating variation such as differences in form, behavior, and physiologies through "phenotypic plasticity", the ability of organisms to respond to environmental cues. These initially environmentally-induced changes could then be refined through genetic modification (e.g., mutation, recombination and hybridization), ultimately leading to the evolution of novel and complex traits that are adaptive for their environments. However, there is still limited empirical evidence demonstrating how plasticity-first evolution occurs, or its general importance, as compared to a more traditional model where novel and complex traits arise by mutation. Using a variety of approaches (transcriptomics, behavioral and endocrine assays, morphometrics), we tested key criteria of the plasticity-first evolution hypothesis in an amphibian system.

We specifically used the spadefoot toad system because closely-related species of spadefoots possess either an ancestral-like feeding strategy or an environmentally-induced (i.e., plastic) cannibalistic feeding strategy. The cannibalistic tadpoles exhibit a novel behavior and an associated array of morphological traits that help them capture and consume live animal prey (including other tadpoles). By comparing species that do or do not exhibit these novel traits, we answered key questions regarding the plasticity-first hypothesis such as, Can novel traits be coaxed from an ancestral-like species under the right environmental conditions? Is there ancestral genetic variation for responses to the environment on which selection can act? Are such traits immediately adaptive, or are there detrimental traits that are induced alongside beneficial ones? 

Findings: First, our work demonstrated that ancestral-like populations harbor ecologically-relevant plasticity in behaviors and morphologies that could, in principle, be selected upon to generate entirely novel traits such as cannibalism. Second, these ancestral-like populations harbor extensive genetic variation in their ability to be plastic; that is, families differ in how they respond to environmental cues. This type of gene-by-environment interaction was found not only at the level of morphologies and behaviors, but also at the level of genome-wide brain gene expression. This work has thereby created a molecular resource that can later be used to determine what specific genes and pathways are modified to refine behaviors in species that possess complex and novel traits like cannibalism. Third, our work revealed that, although plasticity can generate adaptive traits during early life, the carry-over effects of these traits are not necessarily adaptive during later life; we identified several behavioral and physiological later-life traits associated with early-life plasticity that are potentially maladaptive in nature. These findings suggest that the evolution of early-life plastic traits may be constrained by trade-offs incurred during later life.

Taken together, our research has tested and met several key criteria of the plasticity-first hypothesis, providing evidence that environmentally-generated trait variation could play a prevalent and powerful role in the evolution of novelty. At the same time, our research illustrated certain trade-offs associated with early-life plasticity that could limit its evolutionary potential.

Broader Impacts: Our project outcomes have contributed to our understanding of the evolutionary role, potential, and limitations of plasticity. The project has also provided educational and training opportunities for students including high school (through summer internships specifically for groups that are underrepresented in science) and undergraduate (summer and academic semester) students. In fact, the contributions that undergraduate researchers have made to this project have been so great, 2 resulting publications list them as coauthors. The project has supported and involved 3 graduate students, 2 of which are first-generation college students and 1 of which is from an underrepresented group in science. Students at all levels have participated in career-promoting activities such as presenting their research as posters and talks at nation-wide, professional meetings. The PI additionally worked with Indiana University's Outreach Coordinators to bring STEM modules to K-12 classrooms and to provide activities for IU's annual free and public Science Fest event.
